A Guide to the Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Welfare Interests - General Files, Series P FA325

did.unittitle: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Welfare Interests - General Files, Series P

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The files in this series are divided into 13 subseries, as follows:

American Red Cross, Aid for the Blind, Charities, Cleveland Projects, Homes, Immigration, Jewish Organizations, Negro Organizations, Prisons and Prisoners, Prohibition and Alcoholism, Settlements, Science and Lecture Groups, United Service Organization.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series represent the Rockefeller family's involvement over the course of more than half a century with mainstream charitable and philanthropic organizations. With certain important exceptions, these papers focus on maintenance organizations, i.e., groups handling the chronic problems of the disabled, alcoholics, juvenile delinquents, orphans, the elderly, and the sick. For this reason, much of the correspondence and other material contained here is of a routine nature and constitutes what was once called the "citizenship" obligations of the Rockefeller family.

The interests of John D. Rockefeller, Jr. predominate in these files, in particular his interest in prohibition from about 1910 until Repeal in 1933 and his personal and financial contributions to the success of USO during World War II. Much of John D. Rockefeller, Sr.'s early interest in temperance, prohibition, and settlement work can also be traced in these papers. John D. Rockefeller 3rd, because of his conscious choice to pursue a career in philanthropy, is also well represented, in particular through his involvement with the youth work of the Community Service Society. Other members of the family appear only occasionally and then in the form of minor contributions to a few organizations.

The most historically significant material contained in the Welfare General Interests series relates to the Prohibition and Temperance movements, the support for black organizations such as the National Urban League and the NAACP, and the pervasive pattern of support for urban reform manifested by office involvement with the settlement house movement in Cleveland and New York City.

Broader streams of change can also be traced through these files, particularly the centralization of philanthropic organization which the Rockefeller family both encouraged and supported. This trend can best be seen in the emergence of the Community Service Society, the Greater New York Fund, the Welfare Council of New York, and other efforts at federation and consolidation.

did.unittitle: American Red Cross
American Red Cross - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mabel T. Boardman's appeal for aid in 1906 declined. Appeals for various Red Cross activities, buildings, and endowment funds declined. John D. Rockefeller, Sr. joined as $1.00 member in 1916. Rockefeller Foundation grants; World War I activities. There is a gap in this file between 1927 and 1937. Nelson A. Rockefeller contributions for Haitian relief, 1954; information on International Red Cross. Correspondents include Mabel T. Boardman, Starr J. Murphy, Frederick T. Gates, Dana S. Creel, Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Will Rogers, Herbert Hoover, Walter Gifford, Nelson A. Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Charities - Greater New York Fund

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. was an honorary sponsor, 1938 Campaign. Winthrop Rockefeller was Chairman for the 1939 Campaign. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s letters to Winthrop Rockefeller encouraging him and discussing his business career. Memos re business's charity obligations. Assessment of the campaign's reorganization. Speeches by E. R. Stettinius, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Henry Ford II, Howard Rusk. John D. Rockefeller 3rd solicited firms for gifts until 1956. Correspondents include Winthrop Aldrich, James Blaine, Walter Gifford, E. R. Stettinius, Henry Ford II, Edgar B. Young, Arthur Jones, Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Winthrop Rockefeller.

Marston, Mary French Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Cleveland Projects - Cleveland Orchestra Concerts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller's first contribution was of $5,000 to the Cleveland Music Hall. This was followed by gifts for special purposes and for underwriting deficits. John D. Rockefeller was a Guarantor for the Orchestra. Starr J. Murphy stopped the underwriting in 1916. There was a personal friendship between John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Mrs. Hughes. An endowment gift was made in 1929. Tickets were purchased throughout the period. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Starr J. Murphy, Adella P. Hughes.

did.unittitle: Homes - Leake and Watts Orphan House

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave in 1919 and 1920 to this Protestant orphanage. Then his advisors questioned the efficacy of institutional care as opposed to foster homes of adoption. The orphanage switched its role to a "model school (boarding) for dependent children." John D. Rockefeller, Jr. contributed from 1925-1928 but later requests were denied on policy grounds. Correspondents include Willard S. Richardson, Thomas B. Appleget.

did.unittitle: Homes - St. Faith's House, Tarrytown

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave annually to this house for unwed mothers but stopped when the House's finances got more tangled. The House closed, then reopened with the aid of a legacy, and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. resumed contributions. In 1948 Mary French Rockefeller became the Vice-President of the House, and she headed the 1950 Building Fund Campaign. Family members gave some special gifts to the campaign, but later appeals were declined. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Mary French Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Jewish Organizations - Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. strongly approved of the federative principle. He helped the Federation in its early years with $50,000 annually from 1926-1931. His gifts were gradually cut due to policy reasons. The Davison Fund gave gifts. In 1950, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $100,000 to the Capital Funds campaign and thereby became a "founder." There is information about Joseph Wilden's 1961 address advocating less sectarianism in Jewish agencies. Correspondents include Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd., Arthur Jones, Paul Warburg.

did.unittitle: Negro Organizations - Riverdale Children's Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Association's name was changed in 1944 from "Colored Orphan Asylum," when it was no longer restricted to Negroes. This represented a switch to foster-home orientation. Here are reports on finances, board disputes, etc. There were regular family and Rockefeller Brothers Fund contributions from 1940 to 1957, ranging from $1,000 to $3,500 annually. Correspondents include Marshall Field, Arthur W. Packard, Dana S. Creel, Winthrop Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Negro Organizations - New York Urban League

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This League chapter dealt with social, welfare, and industrial work in Harlem and the violent conflicts within and between Harlem agencies during the Depression. There is a 1934 Survey and reorganization plan along with the documentation of changes of personnel and plans for merger with the Brooklyn Urban League. In 1944 the merger took place to create the new League of Greater New York. Contributions were made by the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial Fund, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, and Laurance S. Rockefeller.

scopecontent.p: This League chapter dealt with social, welfare, and industrial work in Harlem and the violent conflicts within and between Harlem agencies during the Depression. There is a 1934 Survey and reorganization plan along with the documentation of changes of personnel and plans for merger with the Brooklyn Urban League. In 1944 the merger took place to create the new League of Greater New York. Contributions were made by the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial Fund, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, and Laurance S. Rockefeller.

Negro Organizations - National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rockefeller advisors were divided over the policies and personnel of the NAACP. They saw the necessity of the legal approach but in general preferred education and gradualism as solutions to the race problem. Here is information on lynching, the influence of the Communist Party among Negroes, and the history of the NAACP. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. contributed from 1928 to 1939. Nelson A. Rockefeller contributed in 1951, 1956, and 1959 and was a Life Member. Correspondents include W.E.B DuBois, James Weldon Johnson, Jackson B. Davis, Walter White, W. Alexander, Thomas B. Appleget, Arthur W. Packard, Dana S. Creel.

Rockefeller, Jr. made several contributions through his Special Advisory Committee. Correspondents include Thomas B. Appleget, Arthur Woods, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Abby Aldrich Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Prohibition and Alcoholism - Citizens Committee of One Thousand

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Committee held nationwide conferences on the enforcement of the Volstead Act. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. was a member and contributed about 10% of its annual budget from 1923-1928. He visited President Coolidge. After 1928 there was no more active participation. Correspondents include Arthur Woods, Willard S. Richardson, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Fred B. Smith.

Fosdick and Albert Scott. There is information on the progress of the study, use of the study's data by other authors, and the publishing of a second book. There is a copy of the 1933 press releases on the study.

daodesc.p: Prohibition and Alcoholism - New York Anti-Saloon League, 1914-1917

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There is a description of conditions in New York in 1919 as seen by an avid prohibitionist. The League shifted to law enforcement problems after passage of the Eighteenth Amendment. There were appeals for contributions and a "disagreement" between Raymond B. Fosdick and W. H. Anderson over the decision to cut Rockefeller funds. Here are copies of an open letter of accusation addressed to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. from W. H. Anderson. There is also information on the post-repeal situation. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Raymond B. Fosdick, Willard S. Richardson, William H. Anderson.

scopecontent.p: There is a description of conditions in New York in 1919 as seen by an avid prohibitionist. The League shifted to law enforcement problems after passage of the Eighteenth Amendment. There were appeals for contributions and a "disagreement" between Raymond B. Fosdick and W. H. Anderson over the decision to cut Rockefeller funds. Here are copies of an open letter of accusation addressed to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. from W. H. Anderson. There is also information on the post-repeal situation. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Raymond B. Fosdick, Willard S. Richardson, William H. Anderson.

Settlements - Alta House

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Settlement in Cleveland's "Little Italy" was named after Alta Rockefeller. John D. Rockefeller's annual pledge to the budget was $14,000 from 1916 to 1919. In 1919 the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial Fund took over the annual gifts, reducing them as local support grew. There is information on the Fiftieth Anniversary Celebration and the end of Rockefeller assistance. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Willard S. Richardson.

United Service Organization (USO)
United Service Organization - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Here is detailed information about organizing the USO and its initial fundraising program. Laurance S. Rockefeller gave a speech in Tarrytown and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave an address containing his Credo. There were complaints about USO operations but the program was a general success. The USO was reactivated in 1951 but Rockefeller support declined after 1957. Correspondents include Arthur W. Packard, Dana S. Creel, Laurance S. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Chester Barnard, Lindsay Kimball.

did.unittitle: United Service Organization - John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. held various posts and aided in recruiting high-level personnel and financial arrangements. There are enigmatic references to the USO's problems and a long memo about USO sectarianism. Kimball appraised and reported on how a future USO-type agency should be operated. There was planning for a post-war USO and liquidation and reactivation. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. continued to help in an unofficial capacity and expressed disapproval of rapid demobilization and a naive attitude about post-war "peace." Correspondents include Lindsay Kimball, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Arthur W. Packard, Thomas E. Dewey, Winthrop Aldrich, Harper Sibley, General F. Osborn, Walter Hoving, Chester Barnard, W. Spencer Robertson.
